deterministic-test.description: Test a scenario with 0 km radius ring destruction. Only the diseased unit should be destroyed.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 2 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of detection vs. the number of days a unit has been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detection vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1.
The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately. The authorities can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day.
There is no spread or vaccination.

deterministic-test.description: Run again, but with 0.5 km radius ring destruction. The closest units are 1 km away, so again only the diseased unit should be destroyed.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 2 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of detection vs. the number of days a unit has been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detection vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1.
The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately. The authorities can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day.
There is no spread or vaccination.

deterministic-test.description: Run again, but with 1 km radius ring destruction. Units 2, 5, 7, and 10 should be destroyed.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 2 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of detection vs. the number of days a unit has been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detection vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1.
The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately. The authorities can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day.
There is no spread or vaccination.

deterministic-test.description: Run again, but with 2.5 km radius ring destruction. All units except 12 should be destroyed.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 2 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of detection vs. the number of days a unit has been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detection vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1.
The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately. The authorities can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day.
There is no spread or vaccination.

deterministic-test.description:
Test a scenario where the disease is spreading. Use airborne spread with infection certain at 1 km but prevent spread farther than 1 km.
In this first test there is no destruction, to confirm that spread acts as we expect. The disease should spread every second day because of the 1 day latent period. It should spread outward in a ring; the immunity period should prevent spread back inward. So:
units 2, 5, 7, and 10 should become infected on day 2
units 1, 3, 4, 9, 11, and 14 should become infected on day 4
units 0, 8, 13, and 16 should become infected on day 6
unit 12 should become infected on day 8
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 3 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of airborne spread at 1 km is 0.505, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 25 km.
There is no detection, vaccination, or destruction.

deterministic-test.description: Run again, but with 1 km ring destruction. This should prevent spread. The first wave of infections (units 2, 5, 7, and 10) will be latent (not yet able to spread the disease) on the day that the index unit (6) is destroyed. So units 2, 5, 7 and 10 will be destroyed before they can go infectious.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 3 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of airborne spread at 1 km is 0.505, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 25 km.
The probability of detection vs. the number of days a unit has been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detection vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1.
The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately. The authorities can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day.
There is no vaccination.

deterministic-test.short-name: spread 1 km + 1 day delay + 1 km radius destruction
deterministic-test.description: Run again, but with a 1 day delay for setting up a destruction program. The delay will allow the first wave cases (units 2, 5, 7, and 10) to become infectious for a day and start a second wave.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 3 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of airborne spread at 1 km is 0.505, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 25 km.
The probability of detection vs. the number of days a unit has been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detection vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1.
The authorities require 1 day to set up a destruction program before beginning. The authorities can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day.
There is no vaccination.

deterministic-test.short-name: spread 1 km + 2 day delay + 1 km radius destruction
deterministic-test.description: Run again, but with a 2 day delay for setting up a destruction program. The delay will allow the first wave cases (units 2, 5, 7, and 10) to become infectious for a day and start a second wave.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 3 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of airborne spread at 1 km is 0.505, and the maximum distance of airborne spread is 25 km.
The probability of detection vs. the number of days a unit has been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detection vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1.
The authorities require 2 days to set up a destruction program before beginning. The authorities can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day.
There is no vaccination.

deterministic-test.description: Test that production types that trigger destruction rings and production types that are destroyed can be specified independently. In this baseline scenario, no production types trigger destruction rings and no production types are destroyed.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For all production types, the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 3 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and natural immunity lasts 3 days.
There is no spread.
The probability of detecting diseased units vs. the number of days they have been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detecting diseased units vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1.
The authorities will destroy units that are detected as diseased. The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately. The authorities can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day. There is no vaccination.
Recapping what should happen as a result of all this: - On day 1 units 0 (cattle) and 1 (pigs) will be latent. - On day 2 units 0 and 1 will be Infectious Clinical. They will be detected and marked for destruction. - On day 3 units 0 and 1 will be destroyed.

deterministic-test.description: Test that production types that trigger destruction rings and production types that are destroyed can be specified independently. In this scenario, only cattle units detected as diseased trigger destruction rings, and only cattle units in the rings are destroyed.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For all production types, the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 3 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and natural immunity lasts 3 days.
There is no spread.
The probability of detecting diseased units vs. the number of days they have been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detecting diseased units vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1.
The authorities will destroy units that are detected as diseased. The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately. The authorities can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day. The authorities will destroy cattle within 1.5 km of a detected cattle unit. There is no vaccination.
Recapping what should happen as a result of all this: - On day 1 units 0 (cattle) and 1 (pigs) will be latent. - On day 2 units 0 and 1 will be Infectious Clinical. They will be detected and marked for destruction. Unit 2 will be marked for destruction because it is a cattle unit within 1.5 km of a detected cattle unit. - On day 3 units 0, 1, and 2 will be destroyed.

deterministic-test.description: Test that production types that trigger destruction rings and production types that are destroyed can be specified independently. In this scenario, only cattle units detected as diseased trigger destruction rings, and only pig units in the rings are destroyed.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For all production types, the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 3 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and natural immunity lasts 3 days.
There is no spread.
The probability of detecting diseased units vs. the number of days they have been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detecting diseased units vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1.
The authorities will destroy units that are detected as diseased. The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately. The authorities can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day. The authorities will destroy pigs within 1.5 km of a detected cattle unit. There is no vaccination.
Recapping what should happen as a result of all this: - On day 1 units 0 (cattle) and 1 (pigs) will be latent. - On day 2 units 0 and 1 will be Infectious Clinical. They will be detected and marked for destruction. Unit 3 will be marked for destruction because it is a pig unit within 1.5 km of a detected cattle unit. - On day 3 units 0, 1, and 3 will be destroyed.

deterministic-test.description: Test that production types that trigger destruction rings and production types that are destroyed can be specified independently. In this scenario, only cattle units detected as diseased trigger destruction rings, but both cattle and pig units in the rings are destroyed.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For all production types, the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 3 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and natural immunity lasts 3 days.
There is no spread.
The probability of detecting diseased units vs. the number of days they have been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detecting diseased units vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1.
The authorities will destroy units that are detected as diseased. The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately. The authorities can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day. The authorities will destroy cattle and pigs within 1.5 km of a detected cattle unit. There is no vaccination.
Recapping what should happen as a result of all this: - On day 1 units 0 (cattle) and 1 (pigs) will be latent. - On day 2 units 0 and 1 will be Infectious Clinical. They will be detected and marked for destruction. Units 2 and 3 will be marked for destruction because they are cattle and pig units, respectively, within 1.5 km of a detected cattle unit. - On day 3 units 0, 1, 2, and 3 will be destroyed.

deterministic-test.description: Test that production types that trigger destruction rings and production types that are destroyed can be specified independently. In this scenario, only pig units detected as diseased trigger destruction rings, and only cattle units in the rings are destroyed.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For all production types, the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 3 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and natural immunity lasts 3 days.
There is no spread.
The probability of detecting diseased units vs. the number of days they have been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detecting diseased units vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1.
The authorities will destroy units that are detected as diseased. The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately. The authorities can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day. The authorities will destroy cattle within 1.5 km of a detected pig unit. There is no vaccination.
Recapping what should happen as a result of all this: - On day 1 units 0 (cattle) and 1 (pigs) will be latent. - On day 2 units 0 and 1 will be Infectious Clinical. They will be detected and marked for destruction. Unit 4 will be marked for destruction because it is a cattle unit within 1.5 km of a detected pig unit. - On day 3 units 0, 1, and 4 will be destroyed.

deterministic-test.description: Test that production types that trigger destruction rings and production types that are destroyed can be specified independently. In this scenario, only pig units detected as diseased trigger destruction rings, and only pig units in the rings are destroyed.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For all production types, the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 3 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and natural immunity lasts 3 days.
There is no spread.
The probability of detecting diseased units vs. the number of days they have been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detecting diseased units vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1.
The authorities will destroy units that are detected as diseased. The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately. The authorities can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day. The authorities will destroy pigs within 1.5 km of a detected pig unit. There is no vaccination.
Recapping what should happen as a result of all this: - On day 1 units 0 (cattle) and 1 (pigs) will be latent. - On day 2 units 0 and 1 will be Infectious Clinical. They will be detected and marked for destruction. Unit 5 will be marked for destruction because it is a pig unit within 1.5 km of a detected pig unit. - On day 3 units 0, 1, and 5 will be destroyed.

deterministic-test.description: Test that production types that trigger destruction rings and production types that are destroyed can be specified independently. In this scenario, only pig units detected as diseased trigger destruction rings, but both cattle and pig units in the rings are destroyed.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For all production types, the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 3 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and natural immunity lasts 3 days.
There is no spread.
The probability of detecting diseased units vs. the number of days they have been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detecting diseased units vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1.
The authorities will destroy units that are detected as diseased. The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately. The authorities can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day. The authorities will destroy cattle and pigs within 1.5 km of a detected pig unit. There is no vaccination.
Recapping what should happen as a result of all this: - On day 1 units 0 (cattle) and 1 (pigs) will be latent. - On day 2 units 0 and 1 will be Infectious Clinical. They will be detected and marked for destruction. Units 4 and 5 will be marked for destruction because they are cattle and pig units, respectively, within 1.5 km of a detected pig unit. - On day 3 units 0, 1, 4, and 5 will be destroyed.

deterministic-test.description: Test that production types that trigger destruction rings and production types that are destroyed can be specified independently. In this scenario, cattle and pig units detected as diseased trigger destruction rings, but only cattle units in the rings are destroyed.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For all production types, the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 3 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and natural immunity lasts 3 days.
There is no spread.
The probability of detecting diseased units vs. the number of days they have been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detecting diseased units vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1.
The authorities will destroy units that are detected as diseased. The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately. The authorities can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day. The authorities will destroy cattle within 1.5 km of a detected cattle or pig unit. There is no vaccination.
Recapping what should happen as a result of all this: - On day 1 units 0 (cattle) and 1 (pigs) will be latent. - On day 2 units 0 and 1 will be Infectious Clinical. They will be detected and marked for destruction. Units 2 and 4 will be marked for destruction because they are cattle units within 1.5 km of a detected cattle and pig unit, respectively. - On day 3 units 0, 1, 2, and 4 will be destroyed.

deterministic-test.description: Test that production types that trigger destruction rings and production types that are destroyed can be specified independently. In this scenario, cattle and pig units detected as diseased trigger destruction rings, but only pig units in the rings are destroyed.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For all production types, the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 3 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and natural immunity lasts 3 days.
There is no spread.
The probability of detecting diseased units vs. the number of days they have been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detecting diseased units vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1.
The authorities will destroy units that are detected as diseased. The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately. The authorities can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day. The authorities will destroy pigs within 1.5 km of a detected cattle or pig unit. There is no vaccination.
Recapping what should happen as a result of all this: - On day 1 units 0 (cattle) and 1 (pigs) will be latent. - On day 2 units 0 and 1 will be Infectious Clinical. They will be detected and marked for destruction. Units 3 and 5 will be marked for destruction because they are pig units within 1.5 km of a detected cattle and pig unit, respectively. - On day 3 units 0, 1, 3, and 5 will be destroyed.

deterministic-test.description: Test that production types that trigger destruction rings and production types that are destroyed can be specified independently. In this scenario, cattle and pig units detected as diseased trigger destruction rings, and both cattle and pig units in the rings are destroyed.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For all production types, the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 3 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and natural immunity lasts 3 days.
There is no spread.
The probability of detecting diseased units vs. the number of days they have been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detecting diseased units vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1.
The authorities will destroy units that are detected as diseased. The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately. The authorities can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day. The authorities will destroy cattle and pigs within 1.5 km of a detected cattle or pig unit. There is no vaccination.
Recapping what should happen as a result of all this: - On day 1 units 0 (cattle) and 1 (pigs) will be latent. - On day 2 units 0 and 1 will be Infectious Clinical. They will be detected and marked for destruction. Units 2, 3, 4 and 5 will be marked for destruction because they are a cattle unit within 1.5 km of a detected cattle unit (2), a pig unit within 1.5 km of a detected cattle unit (3), a cattle unit within 1.5 km of a detected pig unit (4), and a pig unit within 1.5 km of a detected pig unit (5). - On day 3 units 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 will be destroyed.

deterministic-test.short-name: size destruction rings by production type 1
deterministic-test.description: Test that the radius of a destruction ring can be set by the production type that triggered the ring. In this scenario, detection of a diseased cattle unit triggers a small destruction ring.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For all production types, the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 3 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and natural immunity lasts 3 days.
There is no spread.
The probability of detecting diseased cattle units vs. the number of days they have been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detecting diseased cattle units vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1. The probability of detecting diseased pig units is 0.
The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately. The authorities will destroy units that are detected as diseased. The authorities will destroy cattle and pigs within 1.5 km of a detected cattle unit, or within 2.5 km of a detected pig unit. The authorities can destroy 1 unit per day. The priorities for destruction are: reason (basic > ring) > time waiting > production type (cattle > pigs).
There is no vaccination.
Recapping what should happen as a result of all this: - On day 1 units 0 (cattle) and 1 (pigs) will be latent. - On day 2 units 0 and 1 will be Infectious Clinical. Unit 0 (cattle) will be detected and marked for destruction. Units 2 and 3 will be marked for destruction because they are within 1.5 km of a detected cattle unit. - On day 3 unit 0 will be destroyed because detected units have priority over units in destruction rings. - On day 4 unit 2 will be destroyed because among units in destruction rings, cattle have priority over pigs. - On day 5 unit 3 will be destroyed.

deterministic-test.short-name: size destruction rings by production type 2
deterministic-test.description: Test that the radius of a destruction ring can be set by the production type that triggered the ring. In this scenario, detection of a diseased pig unit triggers a large destruction ring.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For all production types, the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 3 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and natural immunity lasts 3 days.
There is no spread.
The probability of detecting diseased pig units vs. the number of days they have been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detecting diseased pig units vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1. The probability of detecting diseased cattle units is 0.
The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately. The authorities will destroy units that are detected as diseased. The authorities will destroy cattle and pigs within 1.5 km of a detected cattle unit, or within 2.5 km of a detected pig unit. The authorities can destroy 4 units per day. The priorities for destruction are: reason (basic > ring) > time waiting > production type (cattle > pigs).
There is no vaccination.
Recapping what should happen as a result of all this: - On day 1 units 0 (cattle) and 1 (pigs) will be latent. - On day 2 units 0 and 1 will be Infectious Clinical. Unit 1 (pigs) will be detected and marked for destruction. Units 0, 2, 3, 4 and 5 will be marked for destruction because they are within 2.5 km of a detected pig unit. - On day 3 unit 1 will be destroyed because detected units have top priority. Units 0, 2 and 4 will be destroyed because among units in destruction, cattle have priority over pigs. - On day 4 units 3 and 5 will be destroyed.

deterministic-test.description:
Test that units that are marked for destruction are quarantined until the destruction can happen. In this test and the following one, there are three units of different production types:
0->1 2
Units 0 and 2 are infected; the middle unit 1 is not. Unit 0 will try to ship to unit 1. Whether the shipment (and infection) happens will depend on whether unit 1 is quarantined. Unit 1 can be quarantined if unit 2 is detected and a destruction ring is drawn around unit 2.
In this baseline scenario, unit 2 is detected, but the destruction ring is too small to include unit 1. Unit 1 is not marked for destruction, and so unit 1 is not quarantined.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For all production types, the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 3 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and natural immunity lasts 5 days.
The movement rate from sheep units to cattle units is fixed at 1 shipment each day. The distance of shipments is fixed at 10 km. The movement rate multiplier is 0 until the public is aware of the outbreak, then it immediately goes to 1. (This is the opposite of what one might expect from movement controls; its purpose here is to make sure any contact we see between cattle units happens after the creation of destruction rings, not before.) There are no shipments between any other pairs of production types.
Latent units can be the source of an exposure.
The probability of infection given exposure is 1.
The probability of detecting diseased pig units vs. the number of days they have been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detecting diseased pig units vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1. Other production types are not detected.
The authorities require 3 days to set up a destruction program before beginning. The authorities will destroy units that are detected as diseased. Units within 5 km of a detected pig unit will also be destroyed. The authorities can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day.
There is no vaccination.
Recapping what should happen as a result of all this: - On day 1 units 0 (sheep) and 2 (pigs) will be latent. There will be no shipments because the movement rate multiplier is 0. - On day 2 units 0 and 2 will be Infectious Clinical. Unit 2 (pigs) will be detected and marked for destruction. The 5 km radius destruction ring drawn around unit 2 will not be large enough to cover unit 1. - On day 3 (1 day after the first detection) the movement rate multiplier will be 1. Unit 0 (sheep) will ship to and infect unit 1 (cattle). The destruction program will not be ready for 3 more days. - On day 4 unit 1 will be Latent. The destruction program will not be ready for 2 more days. - On day 5 nothing new will happen. The destruction program will not be ready for 1 more day. - On day 6 the destruction program will be ready to begin. Unit 2 will be destroyed.

deterministic-test.description:
Test that units that are marked for destruction are quarantined until the destruction can happen. In this test and the following one, there are three units of different production types:
0->1 2
Units 0 and 2 are infected; the middle unit 1 is not. Unit 0 will try to ship to unit 1. Whether the shipment (and infection) happens will depend on whether unit 1 is quarantined. Unit 1 can be quarantined if unit 2 is detected and a destruction ring is drawn around unit 2.
In the baseline scenario above, unit 2 was detected, but the destruction ring was too small to include unit 1. In this scenario, the destruction ring is large enough to include unit 1. Unit 1 is quarantined and marked for destruction.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For all production types, the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 3 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and natural immunity lasts 5 days.
The movement rate from sheep units to cattle units is fixed at 1 shipment each day. The distance of shipments is fixed at 10 km. The movement rate multiplier is 0 until the public is aware of the outbreak, then it immediately goes to 1. (This is the opposite of what one might expect from movement controls; its purpose here is to make sure any contact we see between cattle units happens after the creation of destruction rings, not before.) There are no shipments between any other pairs of production types.
Latent units can be the source of an exposure.
The probability of infection given exposure is 1.
The probability of detecting diseased pig units vs. the number of days they have been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detecting diseased pig units vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1. Other production types are not detected.
The authorities require 3 days to set up a destruction program before beginning. The authorities will destroy units that are detected as diseased. Units within 15 km of a detected pig unit will also be destroyed. The authorities can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day.
There is no vaccination.
Recapping what should happen as a result of all this: - On day 1 units 0 (sheep) and 2 (pigs) will be latent. There will be no shipments because the movement rate multiplier is 0. - On day 2 units 0 and 2 will be Infectious Clinical. Unit 2 (pigs) will be detected and marked for destruction. The 15 km radius destruction ring drawn around unit 2 will not be large enough to cover unit 1, so unit 1 will be quarantined (effective day 3) and marked for destruction. - On day 3 (1 day after the first detection) the movement rate multiplier will be 1. Unit 0 (sheep) will attempt to ship to unit 1 but will be blocked by the quarantine. The destruction program will not be ready for 3 more days. - On day 4 nothing new will happen. The destruction program will not be ready for 2 more days. - On day 5 nothing new will happen. The destruction program will not be ready for 1 more day. - On day 6 the destruction program will be ready to begin. Units 1 and 2 will be destroyed.

deterministic-test.description:
Test that the simulation's early-exit rules are followed with respect to units waiting for destruction.
In early exit tests 1-3, there are two units. Unit 0 is infected. On day 1 unit 0 is detected and unit 1 is marked for destruction. Different effects can be observed when a) there are resources to destroy unit 1 immediately, b) there are no resources to destroy unit 1 at first, but resources eventually come on-line, or c) there are never resources to destroy unit 1.
In this scenario, there are resources to destroy unit 1 immediately.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 3 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and natural immunity lasts 3 days.
There is no spread.
The probability of detecting a diseased unit vs. the number of days the animals have been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detecting a diseased unit vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1.
The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately. The authorities will destroy units within 10 km of a detected unit. The authorities can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day.
What should happen: - On day 1 unit 0 will be latent. - On day 2 unit 1 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected, and unit 1 will be marked for destruction because it is within 10 km of a detected unit. - On day 3 unit 1 will be destroyed. - On day 4 nothing new will happen. - On day 5 unit 0 will no longer be infectious. Because there are no infectious units left and nothing left to do, the simulation can end.

deterministic-test.description:
Test that the simulation's early-exit rules are followed with respect to units waiting for destruction.
In early exit tests 1-3, there are two units. Unit 0 is infected. On day 1 unit 0 is detected and unit 1 is marked for destruction. Different effects can be observed when a) there are resources to destroy unit 1 immediately, b) there are no resources to destroy unit 1 at first, but resources eventually come on-line, or c) there are never resources to destroy unit 1.
In this scenario, there are no resources to destroy unit 1 at first, but resources eventually come on-line.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 3 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and natural immunity lasts 3 days.
There is no spread.
The probability of detecting a diseased unit vs. the number of days the animals have been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detecting a diseased unit vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1.
The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately. The authorities will destroy units within 10 km of a detected unit. On the first 4 days that destructions could occur, the destruction capacity will be zero. The next day and forward, the destruction capacity is 1 unit per day.
What should happen: - On day 1 unit 0 will be latent. - On day 2 unit 1 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected, and unit 1 will be marked for destruction because it is within 10 km of a detected unit. - Day 3 is the first day that destructions could happen, but there will be no destruction capacity for 4 days. - On day 4 there will be no destruction capacity for another 3 days. - On day 5 unit 0 will no longer be infectious. However, the simulation will keep going because there are still destruction tasks to be done. There will be no destruction capacity for another 2 days. - On day 6 there will be no destruction capacity for another 1 day. - On day 7 unit 1 will be destroyed. - On day 8 unit 1's state will show as Destroyed. Because there are no infectious units left and nothing left to do, the simulation can end.

variable-test.short-name: early exit 2, check end of disease and outbreak
variable-test.description: Test that the end of active disease and the end of the outbreak (which includes all control actions) are properly reported.
variable-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
variable-test.parameter-description:
The parameters are identical to "early exit 2" above.
What should happen: - On day 1 unit 0 will be latent. - On day 2 unit 1 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected, and unit 1 will be marked for destruction because it is within 10 km of a detected unit. - Day 3 is the first day that destructions could happen, but there will be no destruction capacity for 4 days. - On day 4 there will be no destruction capacity for another 3 days. - On day 5 unit 0 will no longer be infectious. The end of the active disease phase will be filled in as day 4. The simulation will keep going because there are still destruction tasks to be done. There will be no destruction capacity for another 2 days. - On day 6 there will be no destruction capacity for another 1 day. - On day 7 unit 1 will be destroyed. - On day 8 unit 1's state will show as Destroyed. Because there are no infectious units left and nothing left to do, the simulation can end. The end of the outbreak will be filled in as day 7.

deterministic-test.description:
Test that the simulation's early-exit rules are followed with respect to units waiting for destruction.
In early exit tests 1-3, there are two units. Unit 0 is infected. On day 1 unit 0 is detected and unit 1 is marked for destruction. Different effects can be observed when a) there are resources to destroy unit 1 immediately, b) there are no resources to destroy unit 1 at first, but resources eventually come on-line, or c) there are never resources to destroy unit 1.
In this scenario, there are never resources to destroy unit 1.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 3 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and natural immunity lasts 3 days.
There is no spread.
The probability of detecting a diseased unit vs. the number of days the animals have been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detecting a diseased unit vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1.
The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately. The authorities will destroy units within 10 km of a detected unit. The authorities can destroy zero units each day.
What should happen: - On day 1 unit 0 will be latent. - On day 2 unit 1 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected, and unit 1 will be marked for destruction because it is within 10 km of a detected unit. - On day 3 nothing new will happen. - On day 4 nothing new will happen. - On day 5 unit 0 will no longer be infectious. Because there are no infectious units left and nothing left to do, the simulation can end.

variable-test.short-name: early exit 3, check end of disease and outbreak
variable-test.description: Test that the end of active disease and the end of the outbreak (which includes all control actions) are properly reported.
variable-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
variable-test.parameter-description:
The parameters are identical to "early exit 3" above.
What should happen: - On day 1 unit 0 will be latent. - On day 2 unit 1 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected, and unit 1 will be marked for destruction because it is within 10 km of a detected unit. - On day 3 nothing new will happen. - On day 4 nothing new will happen. - On day 5 unit 0 will no longer be infectious. The end of the active disease phase will be filled in as day 4. There are units awaiting destruction, but there will never be resources to destroy them, so the end of the outbreak will be filled in as day 4, and the simulation can end.

deterministic-test.description:
Test that the simulation's early-exit rules are followed with respect to units waiting for destruction.
In early exit tests 4-6, there are three units. Unit 0 is infected. On day 1 unit 0 is detected and units 1 and 2 are marked for destruction. Different effects can be observed when a) there are resources to destroy both units, b) there are resources to destroy one unit, then later there are resources to destroy the other, or c) there are resources to destroy one unit, but never resources to destroy the other.
In this scenario, there are resources to destroy both units.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For all production types, the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 3 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and natural immunity lasts 3 days.
There is no spread.
The probability of detecting a diseased unit vs. the number of days the animals have been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detecting a diseased unit vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1.
The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately. The authorities will destroy units within 20 km of a detected unit. On the first 4 days that destructions could occur, the destruction capacity will be zero. The next day and forward, the destruction capacity is 2 units per day.
What should happen: - On day 1 unit 0 will be latent. - On day 2 unit 0 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected, and units 1 and 2 will be marked for destruction because they are within 20 km of a detected unit. - Day 3 is the first day that destructions could happen, but there will be no destruction capacity for 4 days. - On day 4 there will be no destruction capacity for another 3 days. - On day 5 unit 0 will no longer be infectious. However, the simulation will keep going because there are still destruction tasks to be done. There will be no destruction capacity for another 2 days. - On day 6 there will be no destruction capacity for another 1 day. - On day 7 units 1 and 2 will be destroyed. - On day 8 units 1 and 2 will show as Destroyed. Because there are no infectious units left and nothing left to do, the simulation can end.

deterministic-test.description:
Test that the simulation's early-exit rules are followed with respect to units waiting for destruction.
In early exit tests 4-6, there are three units. Unit 0 is infected. On day 1 unit 0 is detected and units 1 and 2 are marked for destruction. Different effects can be observed when a) there are resources to destroy both units, b) there are resources to destroy one unit, then later there are resources to destroy the other, or c) there are resources to destroy one unit, but never resources to destroy the other.
In this scenario, there are resources to destroy one unit, then later there are resources to destroy the other.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For all production types, the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 3 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and natural immunity lasts 3 days.
There is no spread.
The probability of detecting a diseased unit vs. the number of days the animals have been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detecting a diseased unit vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1.
The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately. The authorities will destroy units within 20 km of a detected unit. On the first 4 days that destructions could occur, the destruction capacity will be zero. The next day, the destruction capacity is 1 unit. Another day of zero capacity follows, then on the next day and forward the destruction capacity is 1 unit per day. Cattle have priority over pigs.
What should happen: - On day 1 unit 0 will be latent. - On day 2 unit 0 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected, and units 1 and 2 will be marked for destruction because they are within 20 km of a detected unit. - Day 3 is the first day that destructions could happen, but there will be no destruction capacity for 4 days. - On day 4 there will be no destruction capacity for another 3 days. - On day 5 unit 0 will no longer be infectious. However, the simulation will keep going because there are still destruction tasks to be done. There will be no destruction capacity for another 2 days. - On day 6 there will be no destruction capacity for another 1 day. - On day 7 there is capacity to destroy 1 unit. Unit 1 will be chosen because cattle have priority over pigs. - On day 8 unit 1's state will show as Destroyed. There is no capacity to destroy on day 8. - On day 9 there is capacity to destroy 1 unit. Unit 2 will be destroyed. - On day 10 unit 2's state will show as Destroyed. Because there are no infectious units left and nothing left to do, the simulation can end.

deterministic-test.description:
Test that the simulation's early-exit rules are followed with respect to units waiting for destruction.
In early exit tests 4-6, there are three units. Unit 0 is infected. On day 1 unit 0 is detected and units 1 and 2 are marked for destruction. Different effects can be observed when a) there are resources to destroy both units, b) there are resources to destroy one unit, then later there are resources to destroy the other, or c) there are resources to destroy one unit, but never resources to destroy the other.
In this scenario, there are resources to destroy one unit, but never resources to destroy the other.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For all production types, the latent period lasts 1 day, infectiousness lasts 3 days, clinical signs accompany infectiousness immediately, and natural immunity lasts 3 days.
There is no spread.
The probability of detecting a diseased unit vs. the number of days the animals have been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detecting a diseased unit vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1.
The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately. The authorities will destroy units within 20 km of a detected unit. On the first 4 days that destructions could occur, the destruction capacity will be zero. The next day, the destruction capacity is 1 unit. All subsequent days have zero capacity. Cattle have priority over pigs.
What should happen: - On day 1 unit 0 will be latent. - On day 2 unit 0 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected, and units 1 and 2 will be marked for destruction because they are within 20 km of a detected unit. - Day 3 is the first day that destructions could happen, but there will be no destruction capacity for 4 days. - On day 4 there will be no destruction capacity for another 3 days. - On day 5 unit 0 will no longer be infectious. However, the simulation will keep going because there are still destruction tasks to be done. There will be no destruction capacity for another 2 days. - On day 6 there will be no destruction capacity for another 1 day. - On day 7 there is capacity to destroy 1 unit. Unit 1 will be chosen because cattle have priority over pigs. - On day 8 unit 1's state will show as Destroyed. Because there are no infectious units left and nothing left to do, the simulation can end.

variable-test.description: This is one of a set of 6 scenarios to check that the ring is drawn correctly at all latitudes, and with and without the R-tree index. In this scenario, the ring is at the equator and the R-tree is not used.
variable-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
variable-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, the infectious clinical period lasts 2 days, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of detection vs. the number of days a unit has been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detection vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1.
When a diseased unit is detected, that unit and all units within 1 km will be destroyed. The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately, and they can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day.
There is no spread or vaccination.
What should happen: - On day 1 the infected unit (unit 0) will be Latent. - On day 2 unit 0 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected. Unit 0 and the 46 units around it will be marked for destruction. - On day 3 those units will be destroyed.

variable-test.description: This is one of a set of 6 scenarios to check that the ring is drawn correctly at all latitudes, and with and without the R-tree index. In this scenario, the ring is at the 45th parallel and the R-tree is not used.
variable-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
variable-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, the infectious clinical period lasts 2 days, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of detection vs. the number of days a unit has been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detection vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1.
When a diseased unit is detected, that unit and all units within 1 km will be destroyed. The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately, and they can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day.
There is no spread or vaccination.
What should happen: - On day 1 the infected unit (unit 0) will be Latent. - On day 2 unit 0 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected. Unit 0 and the 46 units around it will be marked for destruction. - On day 3 those units will be destroyed.

variable-test.description: This is one of a set of 6 scenarios to check that the ring is drawn correctly at all latitudes, and with and without the R-tree index. In this scenario, the ring is at the -45th parallel (southern hemisphere) and the R-tree is not used.
variable-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
variable-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, the infectious clinical period lasts 2 days, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of detection vs. the number of days a unit has been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detection vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1.
When a diseased unit is detected, that unit and all units within 1 km will be destroyed. The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately, and they can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day.
There is no spread or vaccination.
What should happen: - On day 1 the infected unit (unit 0) will be Latent. - On day 2 unit 0 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected. Unit 0 and the 46 units around it will be marked for destruction. - On day 3 those units will be destroyed.

The latent period lasts 1 day, the infectious clinical period lasts 2 days, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of detection vs. the number of days a unit has been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detection vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1.

There is no spread or vaccination.
What should happen: - On day 1 the infected unit (unit 0) will be Latent. - On day 2 unit 0 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected. Unit 0 and the 46 units around it will be marked for destruction. - On day 3 those units will be destroyed.

variable-test.description: This is one of a set of 6 scenarios to check that the ring is drawn correctly at all latitudes, and with and without the R-tree index. In this scenario, the ring is at the 45th parallel and the R-tree is used.
variable-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
variable-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, the infectious clinical period lasts 2 days, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of detection vs. the number of days a unit has been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detection vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1.
When a diseased unit is detected, that unit and all units within 1 km will be destroyed. The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately, and they can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day.
There is no spread or vaccination.
What should happen: - On day 1 the infected unit (unit 0) will be Latent. - On day 2 unit 0 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected. Unit 0 and the 46 units around it will be marked for destruction. - On day 3 those units will be destroyed.

variable-test.description: This is one of a set of 6 scenarios to check that the ring is drawn correctly at all latitudes, and with and without the R-tree index. In this scenario, the ring is at the -45th parallel (southern hemisphere) and the R-tree is used.
variable-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
variable-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, the infectious clinical period lasts 2 days, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of detection vs. the number of days a unit has been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detection vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1.
When a diseased unit is detected, that unit and all units within 1 km will be destroyed. The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately, and they can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day.
There is no spread or vaccination.
What should happen: - On day 1 the infected unit (unit 0) will be Latent. - On day 2 unit 0 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected. Unit 0 and the 46 units around it will be marked for destruction. - On day 3 those units will be destroyed.

variable-test.short-name: ring at lat 45, units' locations in projected coordinates
variable-test.description: This test is identical to "ring at lat 45" above, but the units' locations are in projected coordinates instead of latitude and longitude. The units are away from the equator so the Albers Equal Area conic can be used (instead of the cylindrical projection it turns into when the units are all near the equator). The population file also demonstrates the use of a "latitude of false origin" to set at which latitude "y" = 0.
variable-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
variable-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, the infectious clinical period lasts 2 days, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of detection vs. the number of days a unit has been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detection vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1.
When a diseased unit is detected, that unit and all units within 1 km will be destroyed. The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately, and they can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day.
There is no spread or vaccination.
What should happen: - On day 1 the infected unit (unit 0) will be Latent. - On day 2 unit 0 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected. Unit 0 and the 46 units around it will be marked for destruction. - On day 3 those units will be destroyed.

variable-test.short-name: ring at lat 45, using R-tree, units' locations in projected coordinates
variable-test.description: This test is identical to "ring at lat 45, using R-tree" above, but the units' locations are in projected coordinates instead of latitude and longitude. The units are away from the equator so the Albers Equal Area conic can be used (instead of the cylindrical projection it turns into when the units are all near the equator). The population file also demonstrates the use of a "latitude of false origin" to set at which latitude "y" = 0.
variable-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
variable-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, the infectious clinical period lasts 2 days, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of detection vs. the number of days a unit has been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detection vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1.
When a diseased unit is detected, that unit and all units within 1 km will be destroyed. The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately, and they can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day.
There is no spread or vaccination.
What should happen: - On day 1 the infected unit (unit 0) will be Latent. - On day 2 unit 0 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected. Unit 0 and the 46 units around it will be marked for destruction. - On day 3 those units will be destroyed.

variable-test.short-name: initially destroyed unit is not first destruction
variable-test.description: This scenario tests whether an initially destroyed unit is counted as the first destruction in a simulation (it should not be).
variable-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
variable-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, the infectious clinical period lasts 2 days, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of detection vs. the number of days a unit has been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detection vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1.
When a diseased unit is detected, it will be destroyed. The authorities can begin a destruction program immediately, and they can destroy an unlimited/very large number of units each day.
There is no spread or vaccination.
What should happen: - On day 1 unit 0 will be Latent. Unit 1 will already be Destroyed, and we will count 1 destroyed unit (initially destroyed units are counted and reported) but we will not count it as the first destruction during the simulation. - On day 2 unit 0 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected and marked for destruction. - On day 3 unit 0 will be destroyed, and that will count as the first destruction during the simulation.

variable-test.short-name: initially destroyed unit does not count toward average wait time
variable-test.description: This scenario tests whether an initially destroyed unit counts toward the average wait time calculation (it should not).
variable-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
variable-test.parameter-description:
The latent period lasts 1 day, the infectious clinical period lasts 1 day, and immunity lasts 3 days.
The probability of detection vs. the number of days a unit has been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detection vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1.
The authorities will destroy units within 10 km of a detected unit. The authorities can destroy 1 unit each day, starting 2 days after the 1st detection.
There is no spread or vaccination.
What should happen: - On day 1 unit 2 will be Latent. Unit 0 will already be vaccine immune. - On day 2 unit 2 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected and unit 1 will be marked for destruction because it is within 10 km. - On day 4 unit 1 will be destroyed, and the average wait time should be 2 (1 unit committed to destroy on day 2, destroyed on day 4). The initially destroyed unit, which did not wait at all, should not lower that number.
